title: Glencore Value Plunges £18bn In Four months
text:
Tip : Use comma (,) to separate multiple quotes. Learn more... 
Wed, Aug 19, 2015, 10:31 BST - UK Markets close in 5 hrs 59 mins Glencore Value Plunges £18bn In Four months By (c) Sky News 2015 | Sky News – 42 minutes ago View Photo 

Mining and trading firm Glencore (Xetra: A1JAGV - news ) has seen its share value drop by more than half in the past 12 months, with a 43.4% plunge since May. 
In real terms, that means the company shares are worth £17.75bn less than they were less than four months ago - a loss of more than the entire value of Tesco (Xetra: 852647 - news ) . 
In its half-year report released this morning, the commodities giant registered a pre-tax loss of $527m (£336m) in the first six months of 2015, down from a $2.5bn (£1.59bn) profit in the same period of 2014. 
The big driver of the loss was a slew of one-off charges due to pulling out of oil fields in Chad. A total loss of $1.25bn (£800m) was attributed to "other expenses". 
But the sharp decline in oil prices over the past year has also played a part, with the value of a barrel of Brent crude at $48.81, down more than 50% from $101.60 a barrel 12 months ago. 
Other commodities have also been in decline. Coal prices are at their lowest in 12 years, with some analysts pointing out that water and cabbage are priced at higher rates in some parts of the world. 
Copper prices have seen a slump too, registering at a six-year low. 
But Glencore chief executive Ivan Glasenberg said his company was "well positioned" to benefit when the commodities market rose again. 
"Against a challenging backdrop for many of our commodities, we have taken a range of pre-emptive actions in respect of our balance sheet, operations and capital spending/recycling in order to preserve our current credit rating and sustain our track record on equity distributions," he said. 
"We remain by far the most diversified commodity producer and marketer and are well positioned to benefit from any improvement in pricing when it finally and inevitably materialises." 
Ivan Glasenberg himself owns about 8% of the firm's shares, meaning that the loss in value over the last four months has resulted in a personal paper loss of around $1.4bn (£800m).
